history.content:
Depending on the class, 1 NP might not matter much especially if the class is not related to what you want to study.

I'm curious about not passing research units, however. Depending on what you intend to study, graduate programs tend to be research-focused so I might be concerned about not passing research units, more so if the research is related to future research you would do.

children.subject:
Depends on the school, their program, and their admission policies.

When, I've reviewed grad apps, I look at the whole transcript and notice any patterns like that. You should def. mention what happened somewhere.
Just to follow up, if you receive an NP in a class and repeat the course the following semester and get a P, will the NP still be considered during Grad School Admissions?

history.content: Here is my guess: Someone will probably look at your transcript when you apply to grad school. Transcripts are pretty cryptic, but they will probably be a bit concerned about the NP. However, your application will still be evaluated holistically. So if you fail some research units but the professor writes you an amazing letter of rec, you are probably fine. It would probably be a bit more concerning if you failing the research units due to a conflict with the professor/not meeting expectations/etc.

I'm curious if anyone knows how grad schools look upon not passing a P/NP class/research units.

Anyone know if this has been asked before (I couldn't find it)?
history.subject: Grad School Admissions: Not Passing a Class
